title: Learning Competition

author: Sergio Jiménez Celorrio, Carlos III University of Madrid

segmentation: OK so I will be presenting the learning part of IPC 2011.
This part has been colonized with Amanda calls and Andrew calls from the University of Strathclyde.
So let's start first with the motivation.
Why do we need a learning part in the IPC?
What I did is domestic part participants typically try to plan from scratch when addressing a problem, even if they have just solve very similar problem in the learning part.
But we want to do is to promote research in planet that are able to benefit from past experience.
So since the target is different, the format of the competition is also different.
FADEC format of the learning part consists of two different stages.

The further state that is called the learning part where participants try to generate affective domain specific knowledge to improve their planners, and a second state that is called a testing state where we, the organizers, get planners and this domain specific knowledge and tried to evaluate the performance of the planner with and without.
They learn domain specific knowledge.
Let's see these two stages more detail.
Let's go first with the learning.
Right?
So this makes a difference from the deterministic part in the learning part.
We provide participants with three different elements.

We provide participants before the valuation with the description of the domains within PDL with our generator for generating problems in this domain and also with the distribution of the test domain of the test problems, we're going to use for the valuation.
In the competition we have used nine domains.
Two of them are new domains and the other seven domains really useful from previous competitions and all of them are represented in the sixth in the strips fragment of PDL.
We also provide participants with the problem generator so they can generate their own learning examples.

I mean, this way they can produce better quality learning knowledge and also they can use the generator for generating test problems so they can on their own, evaluate the quality of the knowledge they learn before they submit this knowledge to the organizer.
The third element we provide participants its distribution.
The distribution of the test set so participants do not exactly know their problems in the test set, but they know the distribution they are going to follow.
That is, they know the number of objects these problems are going to have.
In order to select this distribution of the problems in the test set, we have followed two different criterias.
First we wanted to have problems that were challenging for planners that were state of the art at the previous IPC and we have done this by selecting distributions of large problems.
As an example, in the blocksworld domain, the test problems in the competition range from 50 blocks to 100 blocks.
Also, to make problem challenge we have isolated problems where the military like section where misses important knowledge to solve these problems.
The second idea we have used for the.

The problem from that distribution is that we have some room for learning these problems and for making sure of about that we have run one of our learning systems to verify that we are able to learn knowledge that is able to improve the planner performance.

So that's all about the learning stage, so for almost one month and a half participants could use these three elements we provide for each domain to generate good domain specific knowledge to improve the performance of their planners.

And after that, when they are learning their stages finished, we use the planet submitted under domain generated by participants to evaluate the performance of this planner with and without the learn knowledge.
So let's have a look to the testing stage.
We have a value.
Do we have evaluated the performance of planners so for?
We have waited longer using a time limit bound of 15 minutes per problem.
We have evaluated each planner mission into different dimension, quality and time.

So that also makes a difference with with the terministic part, because we are also interested in time 'cause you can target learning for improving the performance of a given planner in quality terms or and also in in time terms.
This two dimension for quality and time.
We have measured the performance of the Planner with a learn knowledge and we have also tried to measure their learning performance of these systems.
There for in order to measure the performance of planners, we have used a very similar schema as the one using the deterministic part.
In fact, we have used the same software that was produced for the for generating the result for the terministic part.
But we have to do something different for evaluating the learning performance of the system.
So how are we?
How do we evaluate the performance of consistent disabled to learn?
I have an example here to illustrate the way we evaluate the performance of the learning performance of the systems.
So imagine we have two different planners plan A and Plan B that plan A has a base performance without any knowledge of 10 units, an performance using the learn knowledge of 15 units.
And we have also planner.
We we have that has a base for Formula Five, an performance using their knowledge of them.
So we have to answer the question of which one is the best learner.
So one thing we could usually done in the planning and learning research is measuring the Delta performance.
That is the difference between the base performance on the performance using the Learn knowledge.
So in that case, both planet, according to this metric, would have the same score, but it seems reasonable reasonable that.

Better find out performance so we have introduced here an new metric for.
Competing running performance and this metric is very strong computing the operator ranking for each.
Each planner at each problem using these two dimensions, the best performance under Delta performance.

Now we know how the competition is organized.
We are ready to have a look through.
The results.
We have computed results for a different participants and we have the result we have computed.
It's an analysis of the performance in terms of quality time and for these two dimensions the planning performance and learning performance.
